title: Ticket #856: RFE: ClassAd expression evaluator tool
description:
We have ClassAd expressions in many places in configuration today. Expressions can get very complex. There is no user-friendly way to debug the expressions. Some options include starting daemons and using debug() or passing an expression through a tool with -format. Both of these mechanisms are tricks. Something as simple as adding -format to condor_config_val would be a good step forward, or a "-v -v" option to condor_config_val might even help. 

diff --git a/src/condor_tools/config_val.cpp b/src/condor_tools/config_val.cpp
index 4fe4c8d..8a08478 100644
--- a/src/condor_tools/config_val.cpp
+++ b/src/condor_tools/config_val.cpp
@@ -137,6 +137,7 @@ main( int argc, char* argv[] )
   int      i;
   bool  ask_a_daemon = false;
   bool    verbose = false;
+  int      verbose_count = 0;
   bool    dump_all_variables = false;
   bool    print_config_sources = false;
   bool  write_config = false;
@@ -218,6 +219,7 @@ main( int argc, char* argv[] )
         print_config_sources = true;
      } else if( match_prefix( argv[i], "-verbose" ) ) {
         verbose = true;
+        verbose_count++;
      } else if( match_prefix( argv[i], "-dump" ) ) {
         dump_all_variables = true;
      } else if( match_prefix( argv[i], "-writeconfig" ) ) {
@@ -414,6 +416,11 @@ main( int argc, char* argv[] )
         } else {
            if (verbose) {
               printf("%s: %s\n", tmp, value);
+              if (verbose_count > 1) {
+                 printf("boolean (default: 1): %d\n", param_boolean(tmp, true));
+                 printf("double (default: -1.0): %f\n", param_double(tmp, -1.0));
+                 printf("integer (default: -1): %d\n", param_integer(tmp, -1));
+              }
            } else {
               printf("%s\n", value);
            }

2012-Apr-20 18:37:30 by eje:
I've attached a patch that allows condor_config_val to evaluate a parameter against the daemon's classad, for example: 

# trivial example:
$ condor_config_val -schedd -evaluate UPDATE_INTERVAL
30

Note, there are some use-cases of interest that would not be covered by this new feature. For example, params with common "complicated" expressions that come to mind would be things like:

  • START
  • PREEMPTION_REQUIREMENTS
  • GROUP_SORT_EXPR

The 'startd' daemon classad returns as null, and what you'd more likely want is evaluation with respect to some particular slot ad. PREEMPTION_REQUIREMENTS is with respect to a submitter and remote ad, at negotiation time. GROUP_SORT_EXPR is evaluated with respect to special classads associated internally with each accounting group, etc.

2012-Apr-23 13:43:30 by eje:
TESTING:

Use the following configuration to exercise feature cases: 

SCHEDD.TEST_PARAM_1 = 5 * 1
NEGOTIATOR.TEST_PARAM_1 = 5 * 2
STARTD.TEST_PARAM_1 = 5 * 3

SCHEDD.TEST_PARAM_2 = time()
NEGOTIATOR.TEST_PARAM_2 = time() / 2

Now spin up a pool, and query daemons for their config values to demonstrate behavior with and without the new -evaluate option: 

$ condor_config_val -schedd TEST_PARAM_1
5 * 1
$ condor_config_val -schedd TEST_PARAM_1 -eval
5
$ condor_config_val -neg TEST_PARAM_1
5 * 2
$ condor_config_val -neg TEST_PARAM_1 -eval
10
$ condor_config_val -startd TEST_PARAM_1
5 * 3
$ condor_config_val -startd TEST_PARAM_1 -eval
Warning: Classad for startd daemon 'rorschach' is null, will evaluate expressions against empty classad
15
$ condor_config_val -schedd TEST_PARAM_2
time()
$ condor_config_val -schedd TEST_PARAM_2 -eval
1335205018
$ condor_config_val -neg TEST_PARAM_2
time() / 2
$ condor_config_val -neg TEST_PARAM_2 -eval
667602514
